episode_summary: Andrew reveals how Chicago’s “Bubbly Creek” once sparkled from gas given off by animal carcasses; Dan explores Hawaii’s family-guarded slack‑key guitar tunings; and James tells of the storied La Peregrina pearl briefly lost behind a Windsor Castle sofa. Guest John Lloyd rounds off with shipworms, wood‑eating clams for whom an ice‑lolly’s stick is the most nutritious part.

facts.fact: My fact is, the Chicago River used to be sparkling, but only because of all the animal carcasses floating in it.
My Fact this week is that in Hawaii, a tightly guarded secret that used to be passed down from generation to generation was how people used to tune their guitars.
Okay, my fact this week is that in 1874, the world's largest pearl got lost down the back of a sofa.
Okay, my fact is, for a shipworm, the most nutritious part of an ice lolly is the stick.
